Scheme 1 Mechanism for the reaction. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 The phenol adsorption equilibrium concentration with different catalysts (1) V-Zr/AC (2) V-Zr/MWCNTs (3) V-Zr/Bent (4) V-Zr/C3N4 (5) V-Zr/Al2O3. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 The reaction profile for the oxidation of (a) benzene and (b) phenol. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Catalyst hydroxylation of benzene by V-Zr/AC about the variation of conversion and selectivity to all main reaction products with time on stream. Reaction condition: catalyst, 150 mg; benzene, 1.0 ml; acetonitrile, 3.0 ml; ascorbic acid, 0.7 g; pressure, 3.0 MPa; temperature, 80 °C. Selectivity for other products = (1 – selectivity of phenol – selectivity of quinone). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Reusability of the V-Zr/AC catalyst. Reaction condition: catalyst, 150 mg; benzene, 1.0 ml; acetonitrile, 3.0 ml; ascorbic acid, 0.7 g; pressure, 3.0 MPa; temperature, 80 °C; reaction time, 5 h. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD spectra of (a)NH4Cl (JCPDS: 07-007), (b) V-Zr compound (the powder obtained by grinding), (c) V-Zr/AC, (d)V-Zr/MWCNTs, (e)V-Zr/Bent, (f)V-Zr/C3N4, (g) V-Zr/Al2O3. Vanadium-zirconium catalyst on different support for hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with O2 as the oxidant Weitao Wang a ⁎ Na Li a Leilei Shi a Yangmin Ma a b ⁎ Xiufang Yang a b a College of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering, Shaanxi University of Science & Technology, Xi’an, Shaanxi, 710021, China College of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering Shaanxi University of Science & Technology Xi’an Shaanxi 710021 China b Key Laboratory of Auxiliary Chemistry & Technology for Chemical Industry, Ministry of Education, Xi’an, Shaanxi, 710021, China Key Laboratory of Auxiliary Chemistry & Technology for Chemical Industry Ministry of Education Xi’an Shaanxi 710021 China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: College of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering Shaanxi University of Science & Technology, Xi’an, Shaanxi, 710021, China. College of Chemistry & Chemical Engineering Shaanxi University of Science & Technology Xi’an Shaanxi 710021 China Graphical abstract Vanadium-zirconium catalyst was prepared with zirconium tetrachloride and ammonium metavanadate, which were supported on different supports, such as activated carbon, g-C3N4, MWCNTs (multiwall carbon nano tubes), acidified MWCNTs, bentonite, and γ-Al2O3. Various techniques were employed to characterize the catalysts such as X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, nitrogen adsorption, and Raman spectrum. It was found that Zr4+ and V5+ in the vanadium-zirconium catalyst were dispersed on support in the form of zirconium pyrovanadate. The performance of catalysts on hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with O2 as the oxidant was investigated. The vanadium-zirconium catalyst with different supports showed different catalytic performance and the reason was studied. It was found that the catalytic performance was related to the nature of the supports including the surface area and the composition of the supports. The yield of phenol reached to 8.6% and selectivity reached to about 80% when the activated carbon acted as support. Kinetic study showed that the first step of the consecutive reaction was first order for benzene and the second step was first order for phenol. Keywords Benzene Hydroxylation Phenol Molecular oxygen V-Zr catalyst 1 Introduction Phenol is an important chemical intermediate for synthesis of dye, pharmaceuticals, pesticide, resin and so on [1–4]. Currently, phenol is produced in industry by the cumene process that involves three steps: propylation of benzene, autoxidation to cumene hydroperoxide, and Hock rearrangement [5]. This industrial route requires high pressure and temperature, and strong acidic condition. The overall yield of phenol from benzene is less than 5%. In recent years, direct oxidization of benzene to phenol was extensively studied for its clean process [6–9]. Considering the difficulty in the activation C–H bonds of benzene and the higher reactivity of phenol than that of benzene, the conversion of benzene to phenol with high efficiency is still a challenge, which prompts the exploration of excellent and economical catalysts for the title reaction. The catalyst containing V, Cu, Fe and Pd or Re have appeared for oxidization of benzene to phenol in the past decades. In 1987, ascorbic acid was used as co-reductant with the CuCl as the catalyst in Orita group [10], and the phenol yield was 0.23%. In 1995, Tsuruya [11] used the zeolites loaded with Cu as catalyst, with a phenol yield of 1.69%. In 1999, Tsuruya [12] used the V/SiO2 as catalyst for hydroxylation of benzene to phenol, with the phenol yield of 3.7%. Among the reported catalysts, vanadium-containing catalysts are more effective for direct hydroxylation of benzene to phenol. In a past few years, various types of catalytic hydroxylation processes of benzene to phenol with vanadium-containing catalyst have been reported [13–15]. The most studied catalysts of vanadium-containing catalyst for the hydroxylation benzene to phenol are supported vanadium catalysts and polyoxometalates (POMs) catalyst, especially supported vanadium catalysts which have become spotlight in hydroxylation benzene to phenol. Different vanadium catalyst with various supports was studied for hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with molecular oxygen as the oxidant to improve the yield and selectivity of phenol, such as V/SiO2 [16], V x O y @C [17], V-AlPO5 [18], VO x /SBA-15 [19], VO x /TiO2 [20], V-SBA-16 [21] and VO2-defects/MWCNTs [22]. It was reported that the activity of the reaction was related to the vanadium species [23]. However, the effects of the supports on the title reaction are rarely reported [24,25]. The supports of the catalyst could influence the activity and selectivity of phenol. Therefore, to illustrate the effects of the catalyst supports is important for the hydroxylation of benzene to phenol. Various metal was selected as the secondary metal to modify the catalytic performance of vanadium contained catalyst such as V-Mo oxides/SiO2 [26], V-Nb modified MCM-41 [27], V-Ce/SiO2 [28], V-Ag/TiO2 [29]. To our best knowledge, to date, there was no report about Zr oxide modified vanadium oxide catalyst for hydroxylation of benzene to phenol. In this present, synthesis of V-Zr catalyst was developed with the convenient co-precipitation method. The influence of the supports on the activity and selectivity was important. Therefore, various common used supports, such as activated carbon, g-C3N4 (graphite carbon nitride), MWCNTs (multiwall carbon nano tubes), acidified MWCNTs, bentonite, and γ-Al2O3, were employed to investigate the effect of the support on the catalytic performance. The catalyst with different supports were characterized to study the reason for the different performance on the hydroxylation of benzene to phenol. Moreover, kinetic study was conducted to illustrate the effect of factors on the selectivity and yield of phenol. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Benzene, acetonitrile, methanol was purchased from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The NH4VO3 (ammonium metavanadate), ZrCl4 (zirconium tetrachloride) were obtained from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. All the reagents and solvents were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of the catalysts The V-Zr/AC catalyst was obtained by the co-precipitation method. Typically, the 20% loading capacity of the catalyst was prepared as follow. 14.2712 g activated carbon (AC) and 2.2987 g (0.019 mol) ammonium metavanadate were mixed uniformly in 30 ml DMF, and then the above mixture was stirred for 30 min at 30 °C. 1.2691 g (0.005 mol) zirconium tetrachloride dissolved in a certain amount DMF was added in the above mixture. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 6 h. Subsequently, it was filtered and then washed by DMF. The V-Zr/AC-20 catalyst was obtained after it was dried at 80 °C for 10 h. The different loading capacity catalysts were prepared over the parallel method, such as V-Zr/AC-10 for 10% loading, and V-Zr/AC-35 for 35% loading. Under the same condition, the catalysts with different supports were prepared, such as multiwall carbon nanotubes (V-Zr/MWCNTs), acidified multiwall carbon nanotubes (V-Zr/MWCNTs-A) [30], g-C3N4 (V-Zr/C3N4) [31], bentonite (V-Zr/Bent), and γ-Al2O3 (V-Zr/Al2O3) [32]. 2.3 Characterization XRD (X-ray Diffraction) images were obtained by using Cu Kα radiation, nickel filter, 40 kV/40 mA, scanning mode of 2 theta/theta, scanning type of continuous scanning, and a scanning range from 3° to 90° at a scanning rate of 8°/min (Ultima IV, Rigaku). XPS (X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy) spectra (Axis Ultra, Kratos Analytical Ltd.) were using 300 W Al Kα radiation with the binding energies calibrated at 284.6 eV from C1s of the adventitious carbon. Asymmetrical XPS peaks were deconvoluted by using the curve-fitting approach with CasaXPS software, as well as by applying Shirley background subtraction and Lorentzian–Gaussian functions (30% L, 70% G). Surface area of the catalysts were conducted by the adsorption of N2 at −196 °C, the catalyst sample was degassed in vacuum at 120 °C for 2 h before N2 adsorption (Gemini VII 2.00, Micromeritics Instrument Corporation). Raman spectra were recorded on a LabRam-1B microscopic Raman spectrometer with 532 nm laser excitation. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of the products were undertaken on FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-twin microscope at an operating voltage of 120 kV. The Q45 environmental scanning electron microscope (SEM) on the sample morphology was measured at 20 kV and 15 mA. The loading content of V and Zr in the catalysts was determined using ICP-OES (PerkinElmer, optima 7000DV). 2.4 Benzene hydroxylation reaction The hydroxylation of benzene to phenol over various catalysts was carried out as follows. The amount of ascorbic acid, reaction temperature and O2 pressure was fixed at 0.7 g, 80 °C and 3.0 MPa, respectively [12,17,33]. Typically, 0.150 g of catalyst, 1.0 ml of benzene (11.25 mmol), 3.0 ml acetonitrile and 3.0 MPa O2 were added into high pressure seal reactor. The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 5 h. After the reaction, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation. The solution was diluted to 25 mL in a volumetric flask. Concentrations of phenol in the solution were measured by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, WAYEE LC 3000-2 Series instrument) using an Ultimate MB-C18 (250 mm × 4.60 mm) column by UV detector at 254 nm wavelength. The mobile phase consisted of a methanol/water solution 40/60 (v/v) fed at a flow-rate of 1.0 mL/min. The injection volume was 20 μL. Benzoquinone, hydroquinone, catechol and some undefined compounds were detected as byproducts. The mass balance was determined as about 97%–100%. The terms of reaction performance were defined as follows: C o n v e r s i o n o f b e n z e n e = ( 1 - m o l e o f b e n z e n e r e s i d u e i n i t i a l m o l e o f b e n z e n e ) × 100 % Y i e l d o f p h e n o l = m o l e o f p h e n o l p r o d u c e d i n i t i a l m o l e o f b e n z e n e × 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y o f p h e n o l = y i e l d o f p h e n o l c o n v e r s i o n o f b e n z e n e × 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y o f b e n z o q u i n o n e = y i e l d o f b e n z o q u i n o n e c o n v e r s i o n o f b e n z e n e × 100 % 2.5 Phenol oxidation reaction The oxidation of phenol reaction over catalysts was processed as follows. Typically, 0.150 g of catalysts, 5 mmol phenol, 3.0 ml acetonitrile and 3.0 MPa O2 were added into high pressure seal reactor. The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 5 h, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and the obtained liquid was analyzed by HPLC. The HPLC analysis condition was the same as that of the benzene hydroxylation reaction. Benzoquinone was the main oxidation products. The conversion of phenol and selectivity of quinone were calculated by standard samples. 2.6 Adsorption of phenol on different catalysts The 0.24 g of phenol and 8.0 ml acetonitrile were mixed to form a series of 8.0 ml of solution. Then the 0.45 g of catalysts (V-Zr/AC, V-Zr/MWCNTs, V-Zr/Bent, V-Zr/C3N4, V-Zr/γ-Al2O3) were added into each solution respectively, and the mixture was stirred at 30 °C for 40 min. The equilibrium concentrations of phenol were determined by HPLC. 2.7 Catalyst recycling The reusability of the catalyst for the benzene hydroxylation reaction was tested under the optimized reaction conditions. At the end of one hydroxylation run, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed with methanol, and dried at 80 °C. Then, the catalyst sample was used in the next run under the same reaction conditions. 2.8 Maximum phenol concentration For a consecutive reaction of type: A ⟶ k 1 B ⟶ k 2 C k 1 and k 2 are the rate constant for first step and second step, respectively. The intermediate B has a maximum concentration. When each step of the reaction is first-order, the maximum concentration of B and the corresponding time can be calculated as Eqs. (1) and (2) [34,35]. The maximum yield of phenol (yieldmax) and selectivity (selectivitymax) were obtained with the c B , m a x by the definition of yield and selectivity in Section 2.4. (1) c B , m a x = c A , 0 k 1 k 2 k 2 k 2 - k 1 (2) t m a x = ln k 1 / k 2 k 1 - k 2 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The screening of the reaction condition It can be found in Table 1 that the conversion of benzene was increased with the increase of the reaction time (Table 1, entry 1–3). The conversion of benzene and yield of phenol was increased when the catalyst amount (Table 1, entry 2, 4 and 5) or the loading of V-Zr on the catalyst (Table 1, entry 2, 6 and 7) was increased. These indicated that the activity increased with the increase of the active sites. However, the selectivity of phenol was decreased with the increase of the activity. These indicated that the conversion of benzene and overoxidation of phenol were related to the amount of the active sites. When active sites were increased, the more active oxygen species were generated and the conversion of benzene and the yield of phenol increased. However, phenol was more thermodynamically and kinetically to be converted than benzene [36]. Therefore, more active oxygen species also can attack phenol to decline the selectivity. The optimal reaction condition: reaction time was 5 h, catalyst amount was 150 mg, and the loading of V-Zr on the catalyst was 20%. 3.2 The screening of the supports of the V-Zr catalysts Catalytic performance of V-Zr catalyst with different supports on hydroxylation of benzene to phenol was tested and the results were listed in Table 2 . When different supports were employed, the activity and the selectivity were varied. V-Zr/MWCNTs gave the yield of phenol similar as the V-Zr/AC (Table 2, entry 1 and 2), but the selectivity was less than the V-Zr/AC, which indicated that the AC was better than the MWCNTs support. This was due to the different shapes and crystallinity of carbon. Compared to V-Zr/MWCNTs, when the MWCNT-A (acidified MWCNTs) was employed as the support, the selectivity of phenol was declined while the activity changed little (Table 2, entry 2 and 3), which implied that the surface functional groups of the supports influenced the selectivity of phenol. The increased oxygen functional groups on the catalyst disfavored the selectivity of phenol [36]. When it was supported on bentonite, or Al2O3, or g-C3N4, the activity was dramatically improved while the selectivity was decreased (Table 2, entry 4, 5 and 6). These results indicated the activity and selectivity for the V-Zr catalyst was influenced by the supports. 3.3 Phenol oxidation reaction The selectivity and activity were significantly influenced by the support types. The hydroxylation of benzene to phenol was a continuous reaction. Therefore, the oxidation of phenol was investigated with different catalyst to study the effect of support on the selectivity under the same reaction condition of hydroxylation of benzene to phenol as depicted in the experimental section. As shown in Table 3 , the catalytic performance of different catalyst was varied with different supports as expected. It can be found that phenol was easily converted to the quinone. The activity order of the V-Zr catalyst in Table 3 for oxidation of phenol was V-Zr/Al2O3 > V-Zr/C3N4 > V-Zr/Bent > V-Zr/MWCNTs > V-Zr/AC, which was the same trend as the decrease order of the selectivity of phenol in Table 2. These implied that the support of catalyst affected the activity of oxidation of phenol. The high activity of oxidation of phenol consequently resulted in the low selectivity of phenol in the hydroxylation of benzene to phenol. 3.4 Adsorption of phenol on different catalysts Previous study found that the adsorption of the phenol on the catalyst influenced the selectivity of phenol [36–38]. Therefore, the adsorption of phenol with different catalysts was investigated in acetonitrile solution. With the same initial concentration of phenol, the adsorption equilibrium concentration with different catalysts was detected as shown in the Fig. 1 . It can be found that the adsorption amount of phenol was varied with the catalyst. The amount of adsorbed phenol was followed the order of V-Zr/Al2O3 > V-Zr/C3N4 > V-Zr/MWCNTs > V-Zr/AC > V-Zr/Bent. The adsorption amount order of phenol was consistent with the order of surface area (Table 4 ), which indicated that the amount of adsorbed phenol on different catalyst was mainly depended on the surface area. Furthermore, the adsorption amount order of phenol on the catalyst except the V-Zr/Bent catalyst was consistent with the decrease order of selectivity of phenol in Table 2. This implied that the adsorption of the phenol on the catalyst affected the oxidation of phenol and consequently influenced the selectivity. High adsorption of phenol led to the high conversion of phenol, and resulted in the low selectivity of phenol in the hydroxylation of benzene to phenol. This was consistent with the reports that the adsorption of phenol influenced on the selectivity of phenol. For V-Zr/Bent, other metals in the bentonite acted as the active sites [39] which improved the overoxidation rate of phenol (Table 3, entry 3) and resulted in high oxidation of phenol and the low selectivity of phenol for the hydroxylation reaction of benzene though V-Zr/Bent had the lowest surface area. The elemental content in different catalysts was shown in Table 4. The ratios of zirconium to vanadium on different catalyst ranged from 0.35 to 0.48. The vanadium oxides on a given support can form polymerized and complex surface vanadium species: VO4 (orthovanadate) → V2O7 (pyrovandate) → (VO3) n (metavanadate) → V10O28 (decavanadate). [40]. The Zr4+ and V5+ in different catalyst had a similar composition with the Zr/V molar ratio of about 0.5. Therefore, it was postulated that the ZrV2O7 was formed. The deviation Zr/V molar ratio from 0.5 was due to the partially formantion of zirconium metavanadate or other polymerized vanadium species. The V content of different catalyst was similar, therefore, the content effect of vanadium on the catalytic performance was not considered. The surface density of vanaidum was varied from 1.6 V atoms/nm−2 to 10.7 atoms/nm−2. V-Zr/AC and V-Zr/Bent had the similar surface V density, however, their catalytic performances were dramatically different due to the different support. Therefore, the difference of the supports was the main reason for the different catalytic performances. 3.5 Catalytic mechanism of the reaction It was reported that TEMPO (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl) can enhance the conversion of benzene in hydroxylation reaction. With the TEMPO added in the reaction system, more active oxygen species would be generated to accelerate the reaction [41]. To further study the effect of different catalyst for the hydroxylation of benzene, the TEMPO was added in the reaction system. When the TEMPO was added into initial reaction, the reaction rate was increased as well as the conversion of benzene and the selectivity of phenol, as shown in Table 5 . It was believed that the active oxygen species was generated on the catalyst from molecular oxygen with the help of ascorbic acid [36]. As shown in the Scheme 1 , the rate of consumption of benzene (or the formation rate of phenol) and the oxidation rate of phenol were the counter effects for the selectivity and yield of phenol. The generation of active oxygen species was enhanced by adding the TEMPO in the reaction system. Consequently, mores benzene can be attacked by the active oxygen species, which contributed to the increase of the rate of benzene conversion. Because the yield of phenol was relatively low at the low conversion level of benzene, the rate of oxidation of phenol varied little. Therefore, the selectivity of phenol was improved. The conversion of benzene and selectivity of phenol was varied with the different V-Zr catalyst after TMEPO was added, which implied that the activity and selectivity was influenced by the supports of the catalyst. 3.6 Kinetic study of the reactions catalyzed by V-Zr/AC As mentioned above, the oxidation reaction was a continuous reaction. The reaction orders of oxidation of benzene to phenol and oxidation of phenol to quinone were concerned from the aspect of kinetic. Kinetic study of the catalytic reaction was then performed by using the decrease of the substrate to evaluate the kinetics of the first oxidation of benzene to phenol. Further oxidation of phenol into quinone was studied in the separated experiments according to the reaction conditions given in the experimental section. Fig. 2 indicated that both oxidations were first order reactions. Data fitting was satisfactory as evidenced by their calculated R2-values of 0.98 and 0.99 for Fig. 2a and b, respectively. This served to definitely clarify the first order consecutive reaction mechanism. Benzene ⟶ k 1 Phenol ⟶ k 2 Quinone The experimental k 1 and k 2 value for oxidation of benzene and oxidation of phenol were 0.01523 h−1 and 0.10658 h−1, respectively. It can be found that the k 1 was less than k 2, which indicated that the phenol was kinetically easier to be oxidized than benzene. The maximum concentration of phenol and the corresponding time can be calculated by the Eqs. (1) and (2). The t max and c phenol,max were 21.3 h and 0.0456 mol/L, respectively. At the reaction time of t max, the yield of phenol and the corresponding selectivity of phenol can be calculated by the Eqs. (3) and (4). (3) Y i e l d m a x = k 1 k 2 k 2 k 2 - k 1 (4) S e l e c t i v i t y a t t h e t m a x = k 1 k 2 k 2 k 2 - k 1 1 - e - k 1 t The yieldmax was the maximum yield of phenol. It can be obtained that the maximum yield of phenol reached 10.3% where the corresponding selectivity of phenol was only 37.1%. The low yield of phenol was due to that k 1 was less than k 2. This implied that the selectivity of phenol was related to the k 1 and k 2. Kinetically, increasing the k 1 by adding TEMPO mentioned above or decreasing the k 2 by inhibiting the oxidation of phenol can improve the selectivity. The experimental activity can be observed by the conversion of benzene, which can be calculated by Eq. (5). (5) C o n v e r s i o n b e n z e n e = 1 - e - k 1 t From Eq. (5), it can be found that the experimental activity was only related to the k 1. Large k 1 contributed to the high activity and can improve the selectivity of phenol according the Eq. (4). Therefore, from the kinetic aspect, to improve the yield and selectivity of phenol, k 1 should be increased while the k 2 should be decreased. Actually, the k 1 was equal to k[Catalyst][O]. [O] was the active oxygen species generated by the molecular oxygen. When the TEMPO was added in the reaction system, the [O] was increased [41]. Therefore, the k 1 was enhanced, resulting in the increase of the conversion of benzene and the increase of selectivity of phenol on V-Zr/AC catalyst. Different catalyst gave the difference in k[Catalyst][O]. Moreover, the oxygen species, [O], was generated by the ascorbic acid and molecular oxygen with the help of catalyst. Therefore, the catalyst influenced k 1 values and, consequently, affected the selectivity and activity for the title reaction. 3.7 Reaction time The effect of reaction time on the catalytic hydroxylation of benzene was also determined (Fig. 3 ). The conversion of benzene, the selectivity for phenol, quinone and other products were varied with the reaction time. The selectivity for phenol slowly increased with the reaction time below 5 h, which indicated that a suitable reaction time was needed. Adfter 5 h, the selectivity for phenol decreased with longer reaction time. This was resulted from overoxidation of the phenol as the selectivity for overoxidation prduct was increased. These was consistent with the characteristic of the consecutive reaction. 3.8 Reusability reaction As shown in Fig. 4 , the conversion of benzene and the yield of phenol changed little after four cycles. However, the selectivity of phenol was slightly decreased after four cycles. Under the reaction condition, it was the acidic environment, therefore, the vanadium ion may polymerize to form the complex surface vanadium oxides species, which contributed to the slight change of selectivity of phenol. 3.9 Characterization of catalysts To insight into the catalyst, the characterization on the catalysts was conducted. The zirconium tetrachloride and ammonium metavanadate can react directly to form the brown red powder, named V-Zr compound, under the solid phase reaction condition by merely grinding. The XRD spectra of the obtained V-Zr compound and different catalyst were shown in Fig. 5 . The NH4Cl was found in V-Zr compound (Fig. 5b), which indicated that the ZrCl4 and NH4VO3 can react and form NH4Cl. The broad peak at 26–30° implied that amorphous substance was formed. The amorphous compound would be the V-Zr compound. It was reported that copper nitrate and ammonium metavanadate, ferric sulfate and ammonium metavanadate can be used to prepare copper vanadate [42] and ferric vanadate [43], respectively. Therefore, it was postulated that amorphous zirconium vanadate was produced by the reaction between ZrCl4 and NH4VO3 by the double decomposition reaction. Due to the Zr/V ratio near 0.5 (Table 4), it was postulated that ZrV2O7 was the main product. The XRD of different catalysts was shown in Fig. 5c–g. The sharp peak at 30–35° in all the catalysts was attributed to NH4Cl, which indicated that the same reaction was undergone between ZrCl4 and NH4VO3 regardless of directly reacting in solid phase or supported on the different supports. These indirectly implied that all the prepared catalyst possessed the same active composition. Other peaks observed except the NH4Cl peak in V-Zr/AC catalyst were attributed to the polymeric vanadium oxides (or VO x ). XPS analysis was conducted to determine the chemical state of Zr and V in the V-Zr/AC before and after reaction. As shown in Fig. 6 , the Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 binding energy appeared at 182.3 eV and 184.7 eV (Fig. 6a), which was attributed to the Zr (IV) [44]. The valence state of Zr was not changed after four times reaction (Fig. 6a and c). The V2p binding energy at 517.4 eV (Fig. 6b) was assigned to the V(V) in fresh catalyst [45]. However, the V2p spectrum of the used catalyst was at 515.6 eV. The peak at 517.4–518.0 eV was ascribed to the V5+ specie and the peak at 516.4–517 eV was recognized as arising from the V4+ species, while the peak at 514.5–515.9 eV was attributed to the V3+ specie [1,36]. It can be found that the reduced V species appeared in the used catalyst. The change of the vanadium species was originated from that the ascorbic acid in the reaction system can reduce the catalyst to generate lower valence of vanadium [46]. The morphology of the supported catalyst (as SEM images shown in Fig. S1) was mainly the morphology of the supports. The morphology of V-Zr/AC catalyst was not uniform (as TEM images shown in Fig. S2). It only can find that the morphology roughly changed after four times used. The V-Zr/AC was characterized by Raman spectrum. As shown in Fig. 7 , the G (graphite) band related to the vibration mode of sp2 domain can be used to explain the degree of graphitization, while the D (disorder) band was associated with structural defects and partially disordered structure of the sp2 domains. The I D/I G ratio was a sensitive measurement of the structure defects of graphitic carbon material [47,48]. A larger I D/I G ratio indicates more defects or amorphous carbon structure in graphitic materials. The I D/I G ratio of before and after reaction were 1.157 and 1.019, respectively, which indicated that the defects of the carbon support changed little. There was a band at around 608 cm−1 corresponding to ZrO2 band [49], which indicated that the zirconium tetrachloride partially hydrolyzed, and then the ZrO2 was formed on the surface of catalyst. But the ZrO2 was the amorphous which could not be observed in the XRD. The band at around 775 cm−1 and 928 cm−1 in Fig. 7a was recognized as the stretching of VO bands in VO x species [50,51]. However, the stretching of VO band shifted to the long wavelength in the used catalyst (Fig. 7b), which implied the formation of the ploymerized vanadium oxides. Under the hydroxylation reaction condition, it was the acidic environment, therefore, the vanadium ion was polymerized to form the complex surface vanadium oxides species [52], which was contributed to the slight change of selectivity of phenol after four cycles of the V-Zr/AC catalyst. 4 Discussion From the characterization, it could be found that the V-Zr catalyst had the same active site. The V-Zr catalyst with different supports had the similar capability to oxidate phenol (Table 3) which indicated that the similar ability to generate the active oxygen species. However, they had different ability to convert benzene (Table 2). These implied that the ability of active oxygen species attacking the benzene was affected by the different supports, which consequently affected the activity (Scheme 1). The activity (activation of benzene or conversion of benzene) was followed the surface area order of the support (Tables 2 and 4). This implied that the surface area of the support influenced the ability of active oxygen speices attacking the benzene. Therefore, it can be induced that benzene was activated by adsorption on the catalyst surface. Adsorbed benzene was activated to form phenol by the oxygen species generated by the active sites on the surface of the catalyst. Based abovementioned facts, it can be induced that the hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with molecular oxygen followed the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism (Scheme 1), which was consistent with the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism for the oxidation of alkanes/alkenes/aromatics [53]. The activity of hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with molecular oxygen is mainly depended on the active site of the catalyst, including the forms and the contents of the catalytic active species. High content of the lower valence vanadium usually led to the high activity [36]. When the vanadium-containing catalyst possessed the same valence of vanadium, high content of vanadium contributed to the high conversion of benzene (Table 1, entry 2, 4 and 5). When the amount of the active content was same, the activity was affected by the nature of the supports. Due to the Langmuir–Hinshelwood mechanism, the surface area of the support influenced the activity since the substrates were adsorbed before reacting. High surface area of the supports resulted in the high activity. Furthermore, the supports providing active sites could also led to the high activity. For example, bentonite support could provide other metal sites as the active sites to have the high activity. In addition, the shape and crystallinity of the support also had the effect on the activity such as V-Zr/AC and V-Zr/ MWCNTs (Table 2, entry 1 and 2). The selectivity of phenol is mostly determined by the kinetic process. Phenol could be oxidated to quinone by none-catalysis and catalysis process [54]. Under the above reaction condition, the oxidation of phenol underwent the catalytic process and was the first order reaction to phenol. The high k 2 led to the fast oxidation of phenol and low selectivity of phenol. High surface area of support resulted in high adsorption of phenol on the catalyst surface, which would increase the catalysis oxidation of phenol and led to the low selectivity of phenol. Strong interaction between phenol and the catalyst resulted in the hard desorption of formed phenol on the catalyst surface and easy re-adsorption of phenol, which made phenol to be overoxidated on the surface (Scheme 1). Therefore, the surface functional groups of the support influenced the selectivity. Hydrophobic support gave the easy desorption of phenol, consequently, improved the selectivity (Table 2, entry 2 and 3). Some additives or solvents can suppress the re-adsorption of phenol, consequently decreased the k 2 to improve the selectivity (Eq. (4)), such as additive of LiOAc [55], sulfolane [56] and solvent of acetic acid [41,57]. Moreover, the selectivity can be kinetically improved by increasing the k 1 (Eq. (4)), such as the addition of TEMPO in Table 5. In all, when k 1 >> k 2, the selectivity would be satisfied. 5 Conclusions Zirconium-vanadium catalysts with different supports were prepared. The ZrV2O7 was formed from the ZrCl4 and NH4VO3 on the surface of the support. The activity and selectivity was affected by the supports of the catalyst. Different supports affected the adsorption of phenol on the catalyst, which influenced the oxidation of phenol. Moreover, the nature of the supports, such as surface area, composition, surface functional group, also influenced the activity and selectivity. Kinetic study indicated that the reaction was a consecutive reaction with both step of first order. Furthermore, it was found that the phenol was kinetically easier oxidized than benzene. Therefore, the study on improving the selectivity and yield of phenol should be conducted from the aspect of kinetic control. coredata.dc:description: Vanadium-zirconium catalyst was prepared with zirconium tetrachloride and ammonium metavanadate, which were supported on different supports, such as activated carbon, g-C3N4, MWCNTs (multiwall carbon nano tubes), acidified MWCNTs, bentonite, and γ-Al2O3. Various techniques were employed to characterize the catalysts such as X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, nitrogen adsorption, and Raman spectrum. It was found that Zr4+ and V5+ in the vanadium-zirconium catalyst were dispersed on support in the form of zirconium pyrovanadate. The performance of catalysts on hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with O2 as the oxidant was investigated. The vanadium-zirconium catalyst with different supports showed different catalytic performance and the reason was studied. It was found that the catalytic performance was related to the nature of the supports including the surface area and the composition of the supports. The yield of phenol reached to 8.6% and selectivity reached to about 80% when the activated carbon acted as support. Kinetic study showed that the first step of the consecutive reaction was first order for benzene and the second step was first order for phenol.
coredata.dc:title: Vanadium-zirconium catalyst on different support for hydroxylation of benzene to phenol with O2 as the oxidant
